keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris suffered a major theft in October 2025, during which nine high-value royal jewels were stolen from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes.

Among the stolen items are a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces from Empress Eugénie’s collection, including a reliquary brooch and a diamond bow brooch.
The emerald necklace was originally gifted by Napoleon in 1810 and later passed through generations before being acquired by the Louvre in 2004 for €3.7 million.
The sapphire diadem, possibly linked to Marie Antoinette, was owned by the Orléans family until 1985 and is now missing, with no known hallmarks from famous French jewelers of the time.
A reliquary brooch containing the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds was crafted in 1855 for Empress Eugénie and acquired by the Louvre in 1887 for over €6.7 million.
The diamond bow brooch, once part of a 4,000-stone belt exhibited at the 1855 Universal Exhibition, was purchased by Caroline Astor in 1887 and later returned to the Louvre in 2008.
A crown belonging to Empress Eugénie was attempted to be stolen but was recovered near the scene, though damaged during the heist.
Experts like Arthur Brand describe the theft as a 'national disaster' due to the items' symbolic and historical value as the 'natural pride of France'.
Theft is believed to have been carried out by four thieves who left on motorcycles, suggesting a well-organized and possibly repeat offender group.
Experts believe the thieves may have dismantled the items to sell the gold and silver or melt them down, indicating a criminal intent to extract monetary value from priceless historical artifacts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, a major theft occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris, where four thieves broke into the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes and stole nine high-value royal artifacts, including a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several items from Empress Eugénie’s collection. These items hold deep historical, cultural, and symbolic significance for France, as they represent key moments in Napoleonic and 19th-century royal history. The emerald necklace, crafted by François-Régnault Nitot and passed through Marie-Louise’s descendants, was acquired by the Louvre in 2004 for €3.7 million. The sapphire diadem, possibly linked to Marie Antoinette and previously held by the Orléans family, was acquired in 1985. The reliquary brooch and diamond bow brooch, both linked to Empress Eugénie, were crafted in the 1850s and later acquired by the Louvre in 1887 and 2008, respectively. One of the stolen items, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered near the scene but was damaged. Experts, including art recovery specialist Arthur Brand, describe the theft as a 'national disaster' due to the irreplaceable historical and cultural value of the pieces. The thieves are believed to have dismantled the items to sell or melt down the gold and silver, indicating a criminal intent focused on monetary gain. The incident has triggered widespread concern in France and globally, with CNN, TF1, and Le Parisien providing extensive reporting on the event and its implications for national heritage security.
